oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Design sketch of the campus of the Tennessee School for the Deaf and Dumb.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural drawings; Buildings; Schools; Dormitories; Rivers
Tennessee School for the Deaf; Deaf -- Education -- Tennessee; Architecture -- Designs and plans -- Presentation drawings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A design drawing of the landscape and buildings of the "Tennessee School for the Deaf and Dumb" by Marr & Holman and Barber & McMurry. Sections of the image are labeled, "Superintendent's residence" in the bottom left, "Dormitory for little boys" in the upper left, "School" in the top center, "Boiler & Laundry Building" in the upper right, and "Two dormitories for girls" in the bottom right. A label reading "Wiles Nashville, Tenn." is on the bottom right corner.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Marr and Holman, Architects (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Marr and Holman Architectural Firm Records, 1911-1929
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Tennessee School for the Deaf is a state-operated K-12 residential and day school for the deaf and hard of hearing established in 1844. Its current campus in the historic Island Park area of Knoxville was designed in 1928 by Thomas S. Marr, who was also deaf. Marr & Holman was a highly-acclaimed architectural firm from Nashville known for its traditional and art deco designs. They designed numerous buildings including the Nashville Post Office and the baseball grandstand at Sulphur Dell Park.
